Steps.HeaderText: Welcome to the SAP Procurement template for Power Platform
Steps.FinishedText: Completed the SAP Procurement template for Power Platform welcome screen.
Steps.Summary:
Microsoft Power Platform transforms the way you view and work with your SAP data.
SAP ERP is a centralized system of record that facilitates the management of data and business processes between many departments within an organization. This complex system of record serves as the primary enterprise resource planning application for many businesses worldwide. The Microsoft Power Platform helps your organization do more with less by using low-code tools to adapt, innovate, and reduce costs.
 
The SAP Procurement template solution allows you to extend your core procure-to-pay business processes enabled within SAP. The template contains the building blocks necessary to streamline all the SAP screens and attributes related to executing a purchasing process into one simple screen in Power Apps. Power Apps is supported further with the automation of processes behind the scenes using Power Automate cloud flows, the SAP ERP Connector, and Microsoft Dataverse.  You can quickly extend these components to meet your local business requirements including, connecting into additional line-of-business systems and workflows.
 
The SAP Procurement template contains the following core procure-to-pay capabilities:
  • Vendor Management
  • Purchasing Requisitions
  • Purchase Orders
  • Goods Receipt
  • Vendor Invoices
  • Vendor Payments
SAP templates for Power Platform help you achieve value by:
  • Increasing time to value: Out-of-the-box templates mean you don't need to spend months researching and experimenting with APIs to get flows working.
  • Reducing technical debt: Avoid custom code in SAP so you can retain a lower technical debt load and position your organization for smoother upgrades in the future.
  • Achieving sustainability: SAP's published APIs have been supported for decades. The flows will continue to work as long as SAP supports their core APIs.
  • Maximizing existing IT investments: Get more out of your core SAP and other line-of-business systems.

Resources.Description: Watch a brief overview decribing the SAP Procurement template.
Learn more about the SAP Procurement template and its capabilities.

Enterprise templates for Power Platform are solutions that serve as starting points for specific use cases and outcomes. They accelerate time to value by allowing you to quickly digitize new processes or extend your technology investments in enterprise resource planning (ERP), customer relationship management (CRM), and human resource (HR) systems.
Discover the SAP Procurement template on Microsoft AppSource.

Steps.HeaderText: Get to know the SAP Procurement template installer
Steps.FinishedText: Completed introduction to the SAP Procurement template installer.
Steps.Summary:
The SAP Procurement template installer walks you through a checklist of manual and automated steps to help you get your Power Platform + SAP Procurement installation up and running as quickly as possible.
 
The installer is organized by stages, activities, and steps. Each stage has a least one activity with specific steps you need to complete.
 
The stages are:
  1. Introduction: Get to know the SAP Procurement template and the SAP Procurement template installer.
  2. Prerequisites: Ensure you have the necessary licensing and environment setup.
  3. Installation & Configuration: Import and deploy the SAP Procurement template solution.
  4. Optional activities: Enable additional features to optimize your deployment and end- user experiences.
  5. Deployment and next steps: Review the installer stages, launch the app, and explore next steps.
To ensure the best chance of a successful installation and deployment of the SAP Procurement template, it's important to complete as many activity steps as possible in each stage before going to the next stage.

Resources.ResourceName: Get started with the SAP Procurement template
Resources.Description: Information to help you get started on installing the SAP Procurement template.

Steps.HeaderText: Overview: Confirm admin access and required licensing steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed overview of confirming required admins and licensing.
Steps.Summary:
The SAP Procurement template requires Power Apps Premium licensing that's above and beyond your standard Microsoft 365 (M365) entitlements. You also need a current SAP subscription.
 
The template installer uses Power Automate desktop flows to help automate manual setup and validation steps. Power Automate desktop requires either an appropriate Microsoft Windows license or Power Automate Premium license to execute the desktop flows. 
 
In this activity, you'll:
  • Confirm you have access to a M365 administrator who can purchase and assign premium licensing.
  • Confirm at least one Power Apps Premium licensing plan has been assigned to your designated users.
  • Confirm licensing to run Power Automate desktop flows.
  • Confirmed your users are licensed to use your SAP subscription.

Steps.HeaderText: Confirm Microsoft 365 administrator access
Steps.FinishedText: Confirmed access to Microsoft 365 administrator
Steps.Summary:
Confirm if you are a Microsoft 365 Global admin or have access to a Global administrator so you can:
  • Update necessary Power Platform and Power BI licensing, services, and subscriptions.
  • Assign high-level admin roles to your team members such as Microsoft Entra ID Global admin or Power Platform admin.

Resources.ResourceName: About admin roles in the Microsoft 365 admin center
Resources.Description: Microsoft 365 or Office 365 subscription comes with a set of admin roles that you can assign to users in your organization using the Microsoft 365 admin center. Each admin role maps to common business functions and gives people in your organization permissions to do specific tasks in the admin centers.

Steps.HeaderText: Confirm access to one or more of the Power Apps Premium licensing plans
Steps.FinishedText: Confirmed access to one or more of the premium Power Apps licensing plans
Steps.Summary:
The template requires Power Apps Premium licensing.
 
Confirm that your intended users have one or more of the following types of premium licenses assigned to them.

Resources.ResourceName: Licensing overview for Microsoft Power Platform
Resources.Description: Provides detailed information about Microsoft Power Platform licensing.
Detailed document regarding licensing Power Platform.

Steps.HeaderText: Confirm Power BI licensing for gateway admin
Steps.FinishedText: Completed confirming access to one or more Power BI licensing plans for gateway admin.
Steps.Summary:
A Power BI license is required for the administrator setting up the SAP on-premises data gateway.
 
Confirm that the administrator has access to one or more of the following Power BI licenses.

Resources.ResourceName: Licensing the Power BI service for users in your organization
Resources.Description: Everyone who uses the Power BI service must have a license. What a user can do depends on the type of per-user license that they have. Licenses are Fabric free, Pro, or Power BI Premium Per User (PPU). The level of access provided by their license depends on whether the workspace is a Premium workspace or not.

Steps.HeaderText: Confirm Power Automate Premium licensing
Steps.FinishedText: Completed confirming access to Power Automate Premium licensing.
Steps.Summary:
The SAP Procurement template installer leverages Power Automate desktop flows to execute a series of tasks and validations that normally be performed manually.
 
These desktop flows need to run on the Windows virtual machine that the on-premises data gateway will be installed on and discussed in a later activity step. Desktop flows require a Power Automate Premium license in order to run in unattended mode.
 
Confirm Power Automate Premium licenses available:

Resources.Description: A chart that lays out the limits that are associated with the different license plans.

Resources.ResourceName: Power Automate desktop prerequisites and limitations
Resources.Description: This article presents all the prerequisites and limitations you should consider before installing and using Power Automate on your desktop.

Steps.HeaderText: Confirm access to SAP System Administrator
Steps.FinishedText: Completed confirming access to SAP administrator
Steps.Summary:
Work with an SAP System Administrator to review your existing SAP licenses. Keep these points in mind:
  • An administrator who has valid S-User access to the SAP system(s) is required to assist through the integration process.
  • The S-User is an SAP Super Administrator and has all the authorizations for the portal and can manage other necessary SAP roles.

Steps.HeaderText: Confirm SAP user licensing and access
Steps.FinishedText: Completed reviewing SAP subscription and user access
Steps.Summary:
Work with your SAP System Administrator to ensure your intended users are licensed and have access to your SAP system.
 
NOTE: Set up user accounts to allow actions.

Steps.HeaderText: Review: Confirm completion of the licensing and access confirmation steps
Steps.FinishedText: Reviewed steps to confirm licensing and access.

Steps.HeaderText: Overview: Ensure admin access and environment setup steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed overview of preparing your environment
Steps.Summary:
Before you install the SAP Procurement template, it's important to confirm that an appropriate Power Platform environment is set up to support it.
 
Additionally, to enable Power Platform to communicate with your on-premises SAP data, an on-premises data gateway needs to be installed on a Windows Virtual Machine (VM) that is provisioned specifically for this purpose.
 
In this activity, you'll:
  • Confirm you have access to a Power Platform administrator.
  • Confirm this is the target environment for the deployment.
  • Confirm that your target environment has a Dataverse database.
  • Confirm you are a System Administrator of the target environment.
  • Confirm access to Windows Virtual Machine with nothing else set up on it.

Steps.HeaderText: Confirm Power Platform administrator access
Steps.FinishedText: Confirmed you have access to Power Platform administrator capabilities.
Steps.Summary:
Depending on your current Power Platform environment setup, deploying the SAP Procurement template may or may not require access to a Power Platform administrator on your Microsoft 365 tenant.
 
It's recommended that you have access to a Power Platform administrator so they can perform the following tasks, if necessary:
  • Update environment policies and settings that you do not have access to.
  • Update environment role assignments.
  • Update data loss prevention (DLP) policies.
  • Manage environment settings.

Resources.ResourceName: What's the role of a Power Platform administrator?
Resources.Description: Administration of Power Apps, Power Automate, Power Pages, and Power Virtual Agents is done through the Power Platform admin center by a Power Platform admin.
Administrate Power Platform environments.
Learn about administrating the Power Platform

Steps.HeaderText: Confirm template installer is in the target environment
Steps.FinishedText: Completed confirming that the template installer is in the target environment.
Steps.Summary:
This SAP Procurement template installer and the SAP Procurement template must be installed in the same environment.
 
Confirm that this template installer is in the SAP Procurement template's target environment. If it isn't, then you need to reinstall this template installer into the designated target environment.

Resources.Description: A Power Platform environment is a space to store, manage, and share your organization's business data, apps, chatbots, and flows. It also serves as a container to separate apps that might have different roles, security requirements, or target audiences. How you choose to use environments depends on your organization and the apps you're trying to build.

Managed Environments is a suite of premium capabilities that allows admins to manage Power Platform at scale with more control, less effort, and more insights. Admins can use Managed Environments with any type of environment. Certain features can be configured upon enabling a Managed Environment. Once an environment is managed, it unlocks additional features across the Power Platform.

Steps.HeaderText: Confirm selected environment has Dataverse provisioned
Steps.FinishedText: Confirmed selected environment has Dataverse provisioned
Steps.Summary:
Your SAP system is your master data governance system and so it contains all your data.
 
There may be times when data needs to be temporarily stored in Microsoft Dataverse before it is complete or approved. Once it is marked ready to be recorded in your SAP system, the data moved from Dataverse to your SAP system.
 
Confirm that the selected environment for the SAP Procurement template is provisioned with Dataverse.

Resources.Description: Dataverse lets you securely store and manage data that's used by business applications. Data within Dataverse is stored within a set of tables. A table is a set of rows (formerly referred to as records) and columns (formerly referred to as fields/attributes). Each column in the table is designed to store a certain type of data, for example, name, age, salary, and so on. Dataverse includes a base set of standard tables that cover typical scenarios, but you can also create custom tables specific t

Steps.HeaderText: Validate that a system administrator is role assigned to you
Steps.FinishedText: Completed validating System Administrator role assigned.
Steps.Summary:
In order to import and create the necessary SAP Procurement template resources in the target deployment environment, the user(s) deploying the template need a system administrator role assigned to them in the target environment.
 
Select the button to validate that you have the minimum assigned System Administrator role in the deployment environment:

Resources.ResourceName: Security roles for environments with a Dataverse database
Resources.Description: If the environment has a Dataverse database, a user must be assigned the System Administrator role instead of the Environment Admin role to have full admin privileges.

Steps.HeaderText: Set up a Windows Virtual Machine
Steps.FinishedText: Confirmed access to Windows Virtual Machine
Steps.Summary:
Set up a Windows Virtual Machine (VM) or provision a server specifically for hosting the on-premises data gateway for SAP integration with Power Platform and ensure that:

  • It meets the recommended requirements for gateway installation and management.
  • You review related considerations. For instance, if you're planning to use Windows authentication, make certain that you install the gateway on a computer that's a member of the same Microsoft Entra ID (Azure AD) environment as the data source.

Resources.Description: Create Linux and Windows virtual machines (VMs) in seconds and reduce costs.
Requirements for a server hosting the on-premises data gateway.

Steps.HeaderText: Review: Confirm completion of environment setup steps
Steps.FinishedText: Steps for completion reviewed

Steps.HeaderText: Overview: Desktop flow setup steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed highlevel steps to complete the Desktop flows activity
Steps.Summary:
The SAP Procurement template installer utilizes Power Automate Desktop (PAD) flows to automate a series of install and validation checks.
 
Set up the installer desktop flows on the same Windows virtual machine that the on-premises data gateway server is to be deployed on so that the flows can operate tasks directly on that machine. This requires you to set up some Power Automate Desktop flows on that targeted machine.
 
In this activity, you'll complete the following steps on the Windows virtual machine:
  • Install Power Automate Desktop.
  • Configure a local desktop flows machine.
  • Share the Power Automate machine for others to access the desktop flows, if needed.
  • Create or select a desktop flow connection to use when importing additional installation desktop flows.
  • Import additional SAP Template Install solution file containing desktop flows.

Resources.Description: Desktop flows broaden the existing robotic process automation (RPA) capabilities in Power Automate and enable you to automate all repetitive desktop processes. Automating is quicker and easier than ever with the new intuitive Power Automate desktop flow designer using the prebuilt drag-and-drop actions or recording your own desktop flows to run later.

Resources.ResourceName: Get started with Power Automate in Windows 11
Resources.Description: Windows 11 allow users to create automations through the preinstalled Power Automate app. Power Automate is a low-code platform that enables home and business users to optimize their workflows and automate repetitive and time-consuming tasks.

Steps.HeaderText: Install Power Automate Desktop on a virtual machine
Steps.FinishedText: Completed installing Power Automate Desktop on virtual machine
Steps.Summary:
Download and install Power Automate on the virtual machine provisioned for the on-premises data gateway.
 
Take these steps:
  1. Download the Power Automate installer. Save the file to your local Windows VM.
  2. Run the Setup.Microsoft.PowerAutomate.exe file.
  3. Follow the instructions in the Power Automate for desktop setup installer.
  4. Make your selections for each feature:
    • Power Automate for desktop is the app you use to build, edit, and run desktop flows
    • Install the Machine-runtime app allows you to connect your machine to the Power Automate cloud and harness the full power of robotic process automation (RPA).
​​​​​​​​​​​​​​NOTE: Power Automate Desktop may already be installed on the machine for certain Windows operating system versions.

Resources.Description: Download and install Power Automate Desktop instructions.

Steps.HeaderText: Configure local Power Automate Desktop machine
Steps.FinishedText: Completed local Power Automate Desktop runtime machine
Steps.Summary:
Power Automate machines are the physical or virtual devices you use to automate desktop processes. When you connect your machine to Power Automate, you can instantly start your desktop automation using any of the available triggers, such as manually starting them from the SAP Procurement installer application.
 
You'll need to configure a local machine on the same Windows VM that you just installed the Power Automate Desktop on. Unfortunately, it will not be possible to use the Hosted RPA option given the need for the desktop flows to access the local machine resources directly.
 
Take the following steps to ensure the local machine is configured for use:
  1. Launch Power Automate machine runtime application.
  2. Sign in to Power Automate machine runtime. Your machine should be automatically registered in the currently selected environment.
  3. If the machine hasn't been registered yet, a message will prompt you to select a machine-running environment. Power Automate will use this environment to run all the triggered desktop flows.
  4. Update the running environment to the target deployment environment listed below.

Resources.Description:
Machines are the physical or virtual devices you use to automate desktop processes. When you connect your machine to Power Automate, you can instantly start your desktop automation using any of the available triggers, such as predefined schedules.

Connecting your machine directly to Power Automate and the cloud allows you to harness the full power of robotic process automation (RPA).

Steps.HeaderText: Share the machine with other deployment team members
Steps.FinishedText: Completed sharing the machine with others on the deployment team.
Steps.Summary:
Share the Power Automate machine with other administrators in your organization who are part of the deployment team and tasked in helping to set up the SAP connectivity items. These same people must also have access to the Windows VM that Power Automate Desktop was installed on.
 
Take the following steps to share the machine:
 
 
  1. Sign in to the Power Automate portal.
  2. Go to Monitor > Machines.
  3. Select your machine from the list, and then select Manage access.
  4. Select Add people and enter the name of the person in your organization with whom you’d like to share the machine.
  5. Select the name of the person you just added and then select Co-owner to grant them access to the machine.

Resources.Description: You can share a machine with other users in your organization and give those users specific permissions to access it.

Steps.HeaderText: Select connections to populate the connection references
Steps.FinishedText: Completed selecting existing connections to populate connection references
Steps.Summary:
Now that the Power Automate Desktop machine has been configured and shared, it's important that a Desktop flow connection is selected or created prior to importing the additional SAP template installer desktop flows in the next step.
 
 
NOTE: The desktop flow connection requires access to the virtual machine that the desktop flows will be hosted on.

Resources.Description: Learn more about the desktop flow connector

A connector is a proxy or a wrapper around an API that allows the underlying service to talk to Microsoft Power Automate, Microsoft Power Apps, and Azure Logic Apps. It provides a way for users to connect their accounts and leverage a set of prebuilt actions and triggers to build their apps and workflows.

Resources.ResourceName: Use a connection reference in a solution
Resources.Description: A connection reference is a solution component that contains a reference to a connection about a specific connector. Both solution-aware canvas apps and operations within a solution-aware flow bind to a connection reference instead of directly to a connection. During solution import into a target environment, a connection is provided for all the connection references so any referencing flows can be turned on automatically after the import completes.

Steps.HeaderText: Import additional desktop flows to support the installer
Steps.FinishedText: Completed importing additional desktop flows to support the installer.
Steps.Summary:
Since Power Automate Desktop is now configured successfully, the SAP Template Installer app can now take advantage of invoking a series of desktop flows that will perform automated checks further on in the installation process.
 
Download and import these desktop flows as a Power Platform solution file into your current environment to support the overall template installation experience.
 
Execute the following steps to download and install the desktop flows:

Resources.Description: Learn how to manually import solutions into your environment.

Resources.ResourceName: SAP Template Installer Desktop Flows Download
Resources.Description: Link to download the additional desktop flows to import into your environment that supports additional gateway setup steps in future activities.

Steps.HeaderText: Review: Confirm completion of desktop flow setup steps
Steps.FinishedText: Confirmed completion of desktop flow activity steps.

Steps.HeaderText: Overview: Data gateway setup steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed reviewing the high-level data gateway steps.
Steps.Summary:
An on-premises data gateway acts as a bridge to provide secure data transfer between on-premises data that isn't in the cloud and Microsoft cloud services.

The on-premises data gateway installation encompasses multiple components installed on the same domain as the Windows virtual machine (VM).
 
In this activity, you'll:
  • Install the most recent version of the Microsoft .NET Framework.
  • Install the most recent version of the on-premises data gateway.
  • Install the most recent version of Microsoft C++ Runtime DLLs.
  • Install the SAP Connector for Microsoft .NET 3.1 (NCo3.1.)
  • Configure optional gateway clusters to support failover.

Resources.ResourceName: Set up on-premises data gateway for SAP integration with Power Platform
Resources.Description: Learn how to install and setup the on-premises data gateway to allow Power Platform to communicate with SAP.

Steps.HeaderText: Install Microsoft .NET Framework
Steps.FinishedText: Completed installing the most recent Microsoft .NET Framework.
Steps.Summary:
Install Microsoft .NET Framework onto the machine.
 
Select the most recent version of the Microsoft .NET Framework listed in the system requirements section on the gateway download page.

Resources.Description: .NET Framework is a Windows-only version of .NET for building client and server applications.
Download the latest on-premises data gateway.

Steps.FinishedText: Completed installing the most recent on-premises data gateway.
Steps.Summary:
Install the most recent version of the on-premises data gateway onto the machine (December 16, 2022, or later):
 
Take these steps:

Resources.Description: Keep your data in Power BI, PowerApps, Logic Apps, and Power Automate up to date using the on-premises data gateway.

Steps.HeaderText: Install Microsoft C++ Runtime DLLs
Steps.FinishedText: Completed installing the most recent version of Microsoft C++ Runtime DLLs.
Steps.Summary:
Install most recent version of Microsoft C++ Runtime DLLs.
 
SAP's NCo 3.1 download requires this library to support the .NET Framework.

Resources.ResourceName: Microsoft Visual C++ Redistributable latest supported downloads
Resources.Description: The Visual C++ Redistributable installs Microsoft C and C++ (MSVC) runtime libraries. These libraries are required by many applications built by using Microsoft C and C++ tools. If your app uses those libraries, a Microsoft Visual C++ Redistributable package must be installed on the target system before you install your app.

Steps.HeaderText: Install SAP Connector for Microsoft .NET 3.1 (NCo3.1)
Steps.FinishedText: Completed installing SAP Connector for Microsoft .NET 3.1 (NCo3.1).
Steps.Summary: Install SAP Connector for Microsoft .NET 3.1 (NCo3.1) on the machine.

Resources.Description: SAP Connector for Microsoft .NET 3.1 (NCo 3.1) allows developers to use BAPIs and remote-enabled function modules in any .NET application (inside-out). You can also access .NET components from any ABAP application by implementing an RFC server in .NET (outside-in).

Steps.HeaderText: Set up a gateway cluster configuration
Steps.FinishedText: Completed setting up a gateway cluster configuration.
Steps.Summary:
On-premises data gateway clusters can be created to avoid single points of failure when accessing on-premises data resources, but it is important to understand how gateway clusters need to be configured when working with SAP.

The gateway uses the SAP NCo connector, and it maintains an internal state of the connection to SAP. For example, if you have Step A in a flow do something in SAP and Step A uses Gateway 1 to make that call, then Gateway 1 knows about the changes you are trying to make.
 
Because the connector maintains an internal state of the connection to SAP, you want all of your calls to be forced to the primary gateway in the cluster. A call is only directed to the second gateway when the primary gateway call fails. To support this scenario, ensure that random load balancing is turned off.
 
Take these steps:

Resources.Description: Setup cluster configuration for on-premises data gateway when connecting to SAP.
On the Data page of the Power Platform admin center, you can view and manage on-premises data gateways.

Steps.HeaderText: Run automated checks to validate the gateway setup
Steps.FinishedText: Completed running automated checks to validate the gateway setup.
Steps.Summary:
By using a Power Automate Desktop flow, let's check to see if the on-premises data gateway was successfully set up.
 
Select the button to execute a desktop flow that executes a series of scripted checks against the machine.

Steps.HeaderText: Overview: High-level authentication configuration steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed reviewing high level authentication configuration steps
Steps.Summary:
​The SAP ERP connector is designed to be used by multiple users of an application; therefore, the connections aren't shared. The user credentials are provided in the connection, while other details required to connect to the SAP system (like server details and security configuration) are provided as part of the action.
 
Enabling single sign-on (SSO) makes it easy to refresh data from SAP while adhering to user-level permissions configured in SAP. There are several ways you can set up SSO for streamlined identity and access management.
 
In this activity, you'll:
  • ​​​​​​Configure Kerberos constrained delegation.
  • Configure SAP ERP to enable using CommonCryptoLib (sapcrypto.dll).
  • Enable SAP SNC for Azure AD and Windows authentication.
  • Set up SAP server and user accounts to allow actions.

Resources.ResourceName: Configure authentication for SAP Procurement solution
Resources.Description: Overview steps to configure authentication types to SAP to be used by the SAP ERP connector.

Steps.HeaderText: Select an authentication type to deploy
Steps.FinishedText: Completed choosing what is the targeted supported authentication type.
Steps.Summary: Select a supported authentication types you wish to deploy:

Steps.HeaderText: Configure Kerberos constrained delegation
Steps.FinishedText: Completed configuring Kerberos constrained delegation.
Steps.Summary:
Kerberos constrained delegation (KCD) provides secure user or service access to resources permitted by administrators without multiple requests for credentials. Kerberos constrained delegation needs to be configured for Windows and Entra ID (Azure AD) authentication.

Run the gateway Windows service as a domain account with Service Principal Names (SPNs) (SetSPN).

Performing the following tasks to setup KCD:

Resources.Description: Instructions on how to configure Kerberos constrained delegation when integrating with SAP.

Kerberos constrained delegation was introduced in Windows Server 2003 to provide a safer form of delegation that could be used by services. When it is configured, constrained delegation restricts the services to which the specified server can act on the behalf of a user. This requires domain administrator privileges to configure a domain account for a service and is restricts the account to a single domain. In today's enterprise, front-end services are not designed to be limited to integration w

Resources.ResourceName: Configure Kerberos-based SSO from Power BI service to on-premises data sources
Resources.Description: Enabling SSO makes it easy for Power BI reports and dashboards to refresh data from on-premises sources while respecting user-level permissions configured on those sources. Use Kerberos constrained delegation to enable seamless SSO connectivity.

Steps.HeaderText: Set up CommonCryptoLib (sapcrypto.dll)
Steps.FinishedText: Completed configuring SAP ERP to enable using CommonCryptoLib (sapcrypto.dll)
Steps.Summary:
To use SSO to access your SAP server, make sure:
  • You configure your SAP server for Kerberos SSO using CommonCryptoLib as its Secure Network Communication (SNC) library.
  • Your SNC name starts with CN.
Take these steps to set up CommonCryptoLib:
  1. Download 64-bit CommonCryptoLib (sapcrypto.dll) version 8.5.25 or later from the SAP Launchpad and copy it to a folder on your gateway machine.
  2. In the same directory where you copied sapcrypto.dll, create a file named sapcrypto.ini, with the following content:
    • ccl/snc/enable_kerberos_in_client_role = 1
    • The .ini file contains configuration information required by CommonCryptoLib to enable SSO in the gateway scenario. Ensure that the path (such as, c:\sapcryptolib\) contains both sapcrypto.ini and sapcrypto.dll. The .dll and .ini files must exist in the same location.
  3. Grant permissions to both the .ini and .dll files to the Authenticated Users group. Both the gateway service user and the Active Directory (AD) user that the service user impersonates need read and execute permissions for both files.
  4. Create a CCL_PROFILE system environment variable and set its value to the path sapcrypto.ini.
  5. Restart the gateway service.

Resources.ResourceName: Configure SAP ERP to enable using CommonCryptoLib (sapcrypto.dll)
Resources.Description: Instructions in enabling using the CommonCryptoLib supporting SSO with your SAP server.
Instructions on how to check and install the CommonCryptoLib

Resources.ResourceName: Use Kerberos single sign-on for SSO to SAP BW using CommonCryptoLib (sapcrypto.dll)
Resources.Description: This article describes how to configure your SAP BW data source to enable SSO from the Power BI service by using CommonCryptoLib (sapcrypto.dll).

Steps.HeaderText: Enable SAP SNC for Microsoft Entra ID and Windows authentication
Steps.FinishedText: Completed enabling SAP SNC for Microsoft Entra ID and Windows authentication.
Steps.Summary:
The SAP ERP connector supports Microsoft Entra ID, formerly Azure AD, and Windows server AD authentication by enabling SAP's Secure Network Communication (SNC). SNC is a software layer in the SAP system architecture that provides an interface to external security products so secure single sign-on to SAP environments can be established. The following property guidance helps with setup.

 
 
PropertyDescription
Use SNCSet to Yes if you want to enable SNC.
SNC libraryThe SNC library name or path relative to NCo installation location or absolute path. Examples are sapcrypto.dll, or c:\sapcryptolib\sapcryptolib.dll.
SNC SSOSpecifies whether the connector uses the identity of the service or the end user credentials. Set to On to use the identity of the end user.
SNC Partner NameThe name of the back-end SNC server. Example, p:CN=SAPserver.
SNC Quality of ProtectionThe quality of service used for SNC communication of this particular destination or server. The default value is defined by the back-end system. The maximum value is defined by the security product used for SNC.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The SAP SNC name for the user must equal the user's Active Directory fully qualified domain name. For example, p:CN=JANEDOE@REDMOND.CORP.CONTOSO.COM must equal JANEDOE@REDMOND.CORP.CONTOSO.COM.
 
NOTE - Microsoft Entra ID auth only—the Active DirectorySAP Service Principal account must have AES 128 or AES 256 defined on the msDS-SupportedEncryptionType attribute.

Steps.HeaderText: Automatically check if authentication was setup successfully
Steps.FinishedText: Completed automatically checking if authentication was setup successfully.
Steps.Summary: By using a Power Automate Desktop flow, let's check to see if authentication was successfully set up by selecting the button. This desktop flow will execute a series of scripted checks against the machine.

Steps.HeaderText: Set up SAP server and user accounts to allow actions
Steps.FinishedText: Completed setting up SAP server and user accounts to allow actions.
Steps.Summary:
Review SAP Note 460089 - Minimum authorization profiles for external RFC programs to learn more about the supported user-account types and the minimum required authorization for each action type, like remote function call (RFC), business application programming interface (BAPI), and intermediate document (IDOC).

SAP user accounts need to access the RFC_Metadata function group and the respective function modules for the following operations:
 
OperationsAccess to function modules
RFC actionsRFC_GROUP_SEARCH and DD_LANGU_TO_ISOLA
Read Table actionEither RFC BBP_RFC_READ_TABLE or RFC_READ_TABLE
Grant strict minimum access to SAP server for your SAP connectionRFC_METADATA_GET and RFC_METADATA_GET_TIMESTAMP

Resources.ResourceName: Set up SAP server and user accounts to allow actions
Resources.Description: Learn how to setup SAP User accounts to support integration with the SAP Procurement template.

Steps.HeaderText: Review: Confirm completion of SAP authentication configuration steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed reviewing SAP authentication configuration steps.

Steps.HeaderText: Overview: High-level steps for importing solutions
Steps.FinishedText: Completed reviewing high level steps for importing solutions
Steps.Summary:
The templates solution files now need to be imported into your environment. Depending upon your deployment plan, you can choose to import either managed or unmanaged versions of the solutions. 
 
In this activity, you'll successfully import into your target environment these two solution files:
  • SAP Base - contains base components used by all SAP templates.
  • SAP Procurement - components specific to the SAP Procurement template and enabling the procure-to-pay process.

Resources.Description: Solutions are the mechanism for implementing ALM in Power Apps and Power Automate.

Steps.HeaderText: Select solution type to import
Steps.FinishedText: Completed selecting solution type to import.
Steps.Summary: Choose which type of solution to import.

Resources.Description: Article that describes the components, tools, and processes needed to implement application lifecycle management (ALM).
Explore the differences between managed and unmanaged solutions.
Understand how solution layering is implemented at the component level and how layering works if choosing to import the managed solutions.

Resources.ResourceName: Overview of pipelines in Power Platform
Resources.Description: Pipelines in Power Platform aim to democratize application lifecycle management (ALM) for Power Platform and Dynamics 365 customers by bringing ALM automation and continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) capabilities into the service in a manner that's more approachable for all makers, admins, and developers.

Steps.HeaderText: Select existing connections to populate connection references
Steps.FinishedText: Completed selecting existing connections to populate connection references.
Steps.Summary:
Power Platform services use connectors, like SAP ERP, to work with external data sources. A connector is a proxy or a wrapper around an application programming interface (API) that allows the underlying service to talk to Power Platform.
 
Create the connections the SAP Procurement template requires before importing the template solutions into your environment so that connection references can be appropriately established.

Resources.Description: A connector is a proxy or a wrapper around an API that allows the underlying service to talk to Microsoft Power Automate, Microsoft Power Apps, and Azure Logic Apps. It provides a way for users to connect their accounts and leverage a set of prebuilt actions and triggers to build their apps and workflows.

Resources.ResourceName: Use a connection reference in a solution
Resources.Description: A connection reference is a solution component that contains a reference to a connection about a specific connector. Both solution-aware canvas apps and operations within a solution-aware flow bind to a connection reference instead of directly to a connection. During solution import into a target environment, a connection is provided for all the connection references so any referencing flows can be turned on automatically after the import completes.

Resources.ResourceName: Set up connection information in the solutions
Resources.Description: Learn about the connections used in the SAP Procurement template solution.
Connector provides access to the org-based database on Microsoft Dataverse in current environment.

SAP ERP is an enterprise resource planning software developed by SAP SE. SAP ERP incorporates the key business functions of an organization. The SAP ERP connector for Power Automate and Power Apps allows you to invoke RFC and BAPI functions using on-premises data gateway.

Steps.HeaderText: Select and configure SAP system properties
Steps.FinishedText: Completed configuring the SAP system properties.
Steps.Summary: For actions that support the SAP system parameter, select the following properties needed for your configuration. The end result will be populated in a properly formatted JSON screen to be used by the SAP Application Server environment variable in the next step.

Resources.Description: For actions that support the SAP system parameter, use the following table for guidance.

Steps.HeaderText: Set up environment variables
Steps.FinishedText: Completed setting up environment variables.
Steps.Summary:
Environment variables are solution components that store parameter keys and values, which then serve as input to various other application objects found in Power Automate flows and Power Apps. Enterprise systems often have multiple connection parameters, and manually entering the parameters into each component can be redundant and time consuming.

The SAP Procurement template uses environment variables within cloud flows to centrally manage and set key properties on the SAP ERP connector flow action steps. There are five values that are required prior to importing the solution files.
 
Enter the needed environment variable information to be used by future steps:

Resources.Description: Learn to configure SAP Procurement template environment variables at the time of installation.

Environment variables store the parameter keys and values, which then serve as input to various other application objects. Separating the parameters from the consuming objects allows you to change the values within the same environment or when you migrate solutions to other environments.

Steps.HeaderText: Import the SAP Base solution file
Steps.FinishedText: Completed importing the SAP Base solution file.
Steps.Summary: Download and import the SAP Base solution file into your target environment by taking the following steps:

Resources.Description: Learn how to manually import solutions into your environment.
Download the SAP Base unmanaged solution file that contains common Power Platform components used across all SAP templates.

Resources.ResourceName: Download SAP Base managed solution file
Resources.Description: Download the SAP Base managed solution file that contains common Power Platform components used across all SAP templates.

Steps.HeaderText: Import the SAP Procurement solution file
Steps.FinishedText: Completed importing the SAP Procurement solution file
Steps.Summary: Download and import the SAP Procurement solution into your target environment by taking the following steps:

Resources.Description: Learn how to manually import solutions into your environment.
Download the SAP Procurement unmanaged solution file that contains the procure to pay specific capabilities.
Download the SAP Procurement managed solution file that contains the procure to pay specific capabilities.

Steps.HeaderText: Review: Confirm completion of all solution-import steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed all solution-import steps.

Steps.HeaderText: Overview: Steps for sharing the app
Steps.FinishedText: Completed app-sharing steps overview.
Steps.Summary:
The SAP Procurement template contains seven applications. There are six canvas apps that support individual parts of the procure-to-pay business process:
  • SAP Vendor Management
  • SAP Purchase Requisitions
  • SAP Purchase Orders
  • SAP Goods Receipts
  • SAP Vendor Invoices
  • SAP Vendor Payments
Additionally, there is one model-driven app targeted toward template administrators that supports the deployment and runtime execution of the SAP Procurement template processes:
  • SAP Template Administrator
Access to these apps and the underlying data need to be governed by sharing with specific users or security groups and Microsoft Dataverse security roles.
 
In this activity you'll:
  • Select which of the six canvas apps you wish to deploy and utilize.
  • Share those canvas apps with specific users or security groups so that those employees can access the apps.
  • Share the SAP Template Administrator model-driven app with appropriate template administrators.

Resources.ResourceName: Set up access control lists in Microsoft Entra ID
Resources.Description: Users only need access to the apps and flows that align to their departmental function. You can create Microsoft Entra ID security groups based on business processes and assign team members to the appropriate groups. The security groups control user access to the apps and visibility to the various components within the apps.
This article explains general security concepts for people who are unfamiliar with them. For more information about the technical aspects of security.

To control who can access restricted or sensitive data and resources and what they can do with them, assign users to security roles. This article provides an overview of security roles and their associated privileges.

Steps.HeaderText: Share the SAP Vendor Management app
Steps.FinishedText: Completed sharing the vendor management app.
Steps.Summary: Choose whether or not to deploy the SAP Vendor Management app and if so, for which security groups or users.

Resources.ResourceName: Get started using the SAP Vendor Management app
Resources.Description: The SAP Vendor Management app is part of the SAP Procurement solution for Microsoft Power Platform. It allows you to do several functions in SAP quicker and easier than using SAP GUI. You can view, update, and create a vendor.

Steps.HeaderText: Share the SAP Purchase Requisitions app
Steps.FinishedText: Completed sharing the purchase requisitions app.
Steps.Summary: Choose whether or not to deploy the SAP Purchase Requisitions app and if so, for which security groups and/or users.

Resources.ResourceName: Get started using the SAP Requisition Management app
Resources.Description: The SAP Requisition Management app is part of the SAP Procurement solution for Microsoft Power Platform. It allows you to do several functions in SAP quicker and easier than using SAP GUI. You can view and update an existing requisition, create a new requisition, and convert a requisition to a purchase order.

Steps.HeaderText: Share the SAP Purchase Orders app
Steps.FinishedText: Completed sharing the purchase orders app.
Steps.Summary: Choose whether or not to deploy the SAP Purchase Orders app and if so, for which security groups or users.

Resources.ResourceName: Get started using the SAP Purchase Order Management app
Resources.Description: The SAP Purchase Order Management app is part of the SAP Procurement solution for Microsoft Power Platform. It allows you to do several functions in SAP quicker and easier than using SAP GUI. You can search for, view, and change an existing purchase order (PO), or create a new PO.

Steps.HeaderText: Share the SAP Goods Receipts app
Steps.FinishedText: Completed sharing the goods receipts app.
Steps.Summary: Choose whether or not to deploy the SAP Goods Receipts app and if so, for which security groups or users.

Resources.ResourceName: Get started using the SAP Goods Receipt Management app
Resources.Description: The SAP Goods Receipt Management app is part of the SAP Procurement solution for Microsoft Power Platform. It allows you to do several functions in SAP quicker and easier than using SAP GUI. You can search for and view an existing goods receipt document and receive goods against a purchase order.

Steps.HeaderText: Share the SAP Vendor Invoices app
Steps.FinishedText: Completed sharing the vendor invoices app
Steps.Summary: Choose whether or not to deploy the SAP Vendor Invoices app and if so, for which security groups or users.

Resources.ResourceName: Get started using the SAP Vendor Invoice Management app
Resources.Description: The SAP Vendor Invoice Management app is part of the SAP Procurement solution for Microsoft Power Platform. It allows you to do several functions in SAP quicker and easier than using SAP GUI. You can view a recent vendor invoice, approve a vendor invoice for payment, and create an invoice against an existing purchase order.

Steps.HeaderText: Share the SAP Vendor Payments app
Steps.FinishedText: Completed sharing the vendor payments app.
Steps.Summary: Choose whether or not to deploy the SAP Vendor Payments app and if so, for which security groups or users.

Resources.ResourceName: Get started using the SAP Vendor Payment management app
Resources.Description: The SAP Vendor Payment Management app is part of the SAP Procurement solution for Microsoft Power Platform. It allows you to search for and view a vendor payment quickly and easily.

Steps.HeaderText: Share the SAP Template Administrator app
Steps.FinishedText: Completed sharing the SAP Template Administrator app.
Steps.Summary:
The SAP Template Administrator app is a model-driven app. The process for sharing a model-driven app is different from sharing a canvas app because it uses role-based security for sharing.
 
Take these steps to get started: 
 
1. Define security roles for the designated administrators who need access to the SAP Template Administrator app.
2. Go to Power Apps maker portal to get a link to manually share the model-driven app with the designated administrators.
 
Refer to the Share a model-driven app resource link for guidance.

Resources.Description: Share a model-driven app to make it available so other users can play it.

Steps.HeaderText: Review: Confirm completion of all app-sharing steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed sharing apps.

Steps.HeaderText: Overview: Steps for sharing and activating flows
Steps.FinishedText: Completed reviewing the overview on the steps to share and activate the flows.
Steps.Summary:
The SAP Procurement template solution contains 29 cloud flows used to integrate with SAP. Depending on which of the six procure-to-pay processes and corresponding canvas power apps you choose to deploy in the previous activity, the supporting cloud flows need to be shared with the same security groups or users in order to enable those flows to leverage the passed in-user credentials when connecting to SAP.
 
In this activity you'll:
  • Configure the necessary flows to be invoked with user run-only access (i.e., shared).

Resources.Description:
Share a cloud flow with others in your organization and guest users so they can also benefit from automation you've created. There are three primary ways to share a cloud flow in Power Automate:

- Add an owner to a cloud flow.
- Share a cloud flow with run-only privileges.
- Share a copy of a cloud flow.

Steps.HeaderText: Share and assign run-only access to flows
Steps.FinishedText: Completed sharing and assigning run-only access to flows
Steps.Summary:
Follow the steps to assign run-only permissions to the following cloud flows that support the procure-to-pay process steps and corresponding canvas apps selected in the previous activity.
 
By granting those users or security groups the run-only permissions to the flow this will allow the flows to leverage their own credentials when communicating with SAP.

Resources.Description: Steps to share the SAP Procurement template cloud flows.

Resources.ResourceName: Share a cloud flow with run-only permissions
Resources.Description: Instant flows (that is, flows that use a manual trigger such as a button or an item being selected) can be shared by using run-only permissions. Any user who's added as a run-only user won't have access to edit or modify the flow in any way; they'll only have permissions to trigger the flow.

Steps.HeaderText: Review: Confirm completion of flow-sharing steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed flow-sharing steps.

Steps.HeaderText: Overview: High-level dropdown field setup steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed reviewing high level drop down field setup steps to complete
Steps.Summary:
SAP requires a constrained list of values on transactions. These values need to be seeded and administered in the apps so they can be bound to the combo box or dropdown controls. This enables your users to make selections from the list of available values. The constrained list of values varies according to what business process is being implemented.
 
In this activity, you'll:
  • Confirm necessary connections used to import SAP domains.
  • Download and import the SAP Template Installer Dropdown Sync solution.
  • Synchronize necessary domain list of values from SAP into Microsoft Dataverse.

Resources.Description: High level overview of SAP drop down values to load in the SAP procurement template.

Steps.HeaderText: Select the connections used for import
Steps.FinishedText: Completed selecting the connections used for import
Steps.Summary:
The SAP Template Installer requires the import of an additional layered solution that contains cloud flows that query your SAP system for specific domain data information to populate in Microsoft Dataverse.
 
Select the SAP ERP connections to use for this import.

Steps.HeaderText: Import the layered SAP dropdown sync solution
Steps.FinishedText: Completed importing the layered SAP dropdown sync solution
Steps.Summary: Take these steps to import the mpa_SAPTemplateInstallerDropDownSync solution:

Resources.ResourceName: SAP Template Installer Drop Downs Sync Solution Download
Resources.Description: Managed solution file to be layered onto the SAP Template Installer solution once Power Platform connectivity to SAP has been established. This solution allows you to automatically sync SAP domain values to the needed list-of-values table in Microsoft Dataverse used by the template.

Steps.HeaderText: Load SAP domain values into Dataverse
Steps.FinishedText: Completed loading SAP domain values into Dataverse.
Steps.Summary: Select the language you wish to import domain values directly from your SAP system into Microsoft Dataverse so that they can be leveraged by the template. This will execute a series of flows imported by the solution in the preview step.

Steps.HeaderText: Validate that the list of values synced successfully from SAP
Steps.FinishedText: Completed validating that the list of values synced successfully from SAP.
Steps.Summary:
Open the SAP Template Administrator app to validate that the list of domain values imported from SAP synced successfully into Microsoft Dataverse.
 
You can quickly and easily make corrections directly in the SAP Template Administrator app by using the Export to Excel | Open in Excel Online capability to view and manage in bulk.

Resources.ResourceName: Learn  Power Platform  Apply seed data Article 12/11/2023 1 contributor In this article Manage menu
Resources.Description: Learn how to quickly view and manage SAP domain values that are synced to Microsoft Dataverse to be used by the SAP Procurement template.

Steps.HeaderText: Review: Confirm completion of dropdown value setup steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed reviewing drop down value setups that were completed

Steps.HeaderText: Overview: Localization steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed overview of localization steps.
Steps.Summary:
All strings in the SAP Procurement template canvas apps are defaulted to English. However, the template apps are all localization ready. This means all Text, Accessible Label, Tool Tip, HintText, InputPlaceHolderText, and Notifications have Power Fx functions built in to check whether a localized string is present for the user's logged-in browser language code. These strings are administered and maintained via the SAP Template Administrator App and read by the canvas apps at runtime.
 
Additionally, all numeric, date, and time values will be displayed by your browser's locale settings.
 
The SAP Template Administrator model-driven app uses built-in native translations capabilities to support localizing the app and follows a different process.
 
In this activity, you'll:
  • Select a desired language to translate the SAP Procurement canvas app strings to.
  • Validate and make necessary modifications to template canvas apps to accommodate strings.
  • Localize the SAP Template Administrator model-driven app.

Resources.Description: For a wide array of languages, Power Apps knows how to properly write out dates, times, currencies, and numbers. The Kudos app is designed to support such.

Steps.HeaderText: Localize SAP canvas app strings
Steps.FinishedText: Completed localizing SAP canvas app strings.
Steps.Summary:
Choose from the list of default languages to translate to by using AI Builder, translator service. 
 
NOTE: Using AI Builder requires AI Builder credits to be allocated to your deployment environment. AI Builder credits come with some specific user licenses or an AI Builder capacity add-on. They are not available by default with a Developer plan.

WARNING: As with any AI generated content, make sure the translations are accurate and appropriate before using. Additionally, control widths may need to be updated in the SAP Procurement canvas apps to accommodate the new string lengths as well as control ordering depending on what language is selected. Translating the strings automatically just removes one step of the process.
 
If your environment does not have access to AI Builder credits, then manually launch the SAP Template Administrator app to create localized strings.

Resources.Description: Learn how to manage localized strings (e.g. Labels, Tool tips, etc...) used by the SAP Procurement Template canvas apps.

Resources.ResourceName: AI Builder licensing and credit management
Resources.Description: Access to AI Builder features within an environment requires AI Builder credits.

Steps.HeaderText: Configure any changes to canvas apps to support localization
Steps.FinishedText: Completed any changes to canvas apps to support localization
Steps.Summary: Make any changes to template canvas apps that you have chosen to deploy such as control widths and/or order of the controls that were identified in the previous steps. Note if you previously imported managed versions of the solutions you will need to make a new unmanaged version of the solution, add the app and make the changes there in order to add your own solution layers.

Resources.Description: Edit any canvas app that you created, or for which you have Co-owner permission. You can edit an app in Power Apps Studio.

Steps.HeaderText: Enable other languages for your environment
Steps.FinishedText: Completed enabling other languages for your environment
Steps.Summary:
Localizing the SAP Template Administrator model-driven app requires you to follow a different set of steps that leverage the native localization capabilities inherit to those types of app versus canvas apps. 

First start by enabling the desired language in your environment by opening and applying the desired language in language settings.

Resources.ResourceName: Regional and language options for your environment
Resources.Description: Enable languages in your organization to display the user interface and Help in a language that’s different from the base language.

Steps.HeaderText: Translate SAP Template Administrator app strings
Steps.FinishedText: Completed translating SAP Template Administrator app strings.
Steps.Summary: Next, follow the steps to export the text from the SAP Template Administrator model-driven app, translate to one or more of the installed environment languages and then reimport that text.

Resources.ResourceName: Translate localizable text for model-driven apps
Resources.Description: If you have customized table or column text, such as column labels or drop-down list values, you can provide the users in your environment who are not working with the base language version of your environment with this customized text in their preferred languages.

Steps.HeaderText: Select language in SAP Template Administrator app personal settings.
Steps.FinishedText: Completed selecting language in SAP Template Administrator app personal settings.
Steps.Summary: Once the language has been installed and text translated, each user needs to change their desired user interface language personal setting within their own SAP Template Administrator app.

Resources.Description: Select the language that you want to see for labels and dialog boxes in the Kudos Administrator app user interface.

Steps.HeaderText: Review: Confirm completion of SAP Procurement Template localization steps
Steps.FinishedText: Finished reviewing completed steps for SAP Procurement Templatelocalization

Steps.HeaderText: Overview: Review SAP template install process, launch the app, and explore next steps
Steps.FinishedText: Completed overview of reviewing, launching, and exploring steps.
Steps.Summary:
You're now in the final stage of the SAP Procurement template installer process. In this activity, you'll: 
  • Review the SAP Procurement template installer process.
  • Launch the SAP Procurement apps.
  • Explore next steps for managing enterprise-grade apps.
 
Congratulations on successfully installing the SAP Procurement template! During this process you should have completed:
 
  1. Prerequisites: Ensure your licensing and environment is ready
  2. Install & Configuration: Imported and deploy the SAP Procurement template solution
  3. Optional Tasks: Enable additional features to optimize your deployment and end user experiences
  4. Finish: Wrap up with additional resources and next steps
To further support deploying and manage SAP Procurement within your larger organization, consider exploring the following topics:
  • Pipelines in Power Power Platform - to support extending, testing and production deployment of Kudos template across multiple Power Platform environments
  • Managed Environments - enable greater governance and control over deployment and management of the Kudos template.
You are now ready to launch and use the SAP Procurement apps you have chosen to deploy by clicking the button(s)

Resources.ResourceName: Set up pipelines in Power Platform
Resources.Description: Create and run pipelines to easily deploy solutions to environments.

Managed Environments is a suite of premium capabilities that allows admins to manage Power Platform at scale with more control, less effort, and more insights. Admins can use Managed Environments with any type of environment. Certain features can be configured upon enabling a Managed Environment. Once an environment is managed, it unlocks additional features across the Power Platform.

Steps.HeaderText: Review template installer process
Steps.FinishedText: Completed reviewing the template installer process
Steps.Summary:
Review the SAP Procurement template installer process to ensure that you completed all the necessary stages to successfully launch the SAP Procurement template apps.
 
Make sure you:
 
• Confirmed all necessary licensing and environment prerequisites
• Set up an on-premises data gateway
• Installed and configured the SAP Procurement template
• Enabled any optional settings like, localization, to further enhance the SAP Procurement app experiences

Steps.FinishedText: Completed launching the app
